Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Remote Delivery of Information Technologies Education in a Rural Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Between 2019 and 2023, Information Technology (IT) jobs are expected to grow 10% in northwest Arkansas. The demand for IT professionals in Arkansas is already outpacing the number of graduates being produced. This project aims to address this need by remotely delivering IT courses to rural students in a six-county area in north-central Arkansas. The use of remote-access labs will provide state of the art, hands-on coursework to these students, thus preparing them for employment as IT technicians in northwest Arkansas. This project has the potential to change the lives of students who are unable to move outside of their local area for IT education or work.

The college will expand delivery of remote content to include the associate degree in Information Technology, and will improve the curriculum by adding new content, including cloud technologies, virtualization, and Internet of Things. The students will have access to real-world problem solving and teamwork in the capstone course, as well as internship opportunities. Such changes will build employability skills into the program so that students are ready for immediate employment after graduation. This program will offer year-round access with multiple entry points, providing more flexible opportunities for program completion. The project has the potential to help diversify the workforce and grow the economy in rural areas by providing access to high-tech jobs for low-income students. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF ATE funding for Northark College's Information Technologies project has significantly transformed the training landscape for skilled technicians in rural areas. This initiative aimed to enhance the delivery of hands-on IT courses, making education more accessible and efficient for students. The primary focus was on expanding course offerings in contemporary and emerging technologies including cloud computing, virtualization, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Key Outcomes

This project resulted in a program with added flexibility of scheduling for participants, an emphasis on contemporary and emerging technologies, and clear pathways for IT and cyber emphases. These changes, along with the steady increase in enrollment and significant increase in completion rates, demonstrate the project’s effectiveness. See Table 1 for enrollment and completion data.

Transformative Changes

  1. Increased Online Availability: Recognizing the challenges faced by working students, Northark modified its program to offer nearly 100% online course availability. This shift allows students to balance their education with full-time employment, with only two optional courses remaining as in-person offerings.
  2. Flexible Entry Points: Previously, students could only enroll in the program during the fall semester. Now, entry-level courses are available year-round, allowing students to start their education in the fall, spring or summer, enhancing their chances for timely completion.
  3. Curriculum Alignment and Expansion: The Associate of Applied Science (AAS) IT degree program is fed by stackable Certificate of Proficiency (CP) and Technical Certificate (TC) programs.  The AAS IT is aligned with newer degrees such as the Associate of Science (AS) in IT and AS in Cybersecurity. This alignment ensures that students have clear pathways and options based on their interests.
  4. Certification Alignment: The curriculum framework now corresponds with national CompTIA certification exams, providing students with industry-recognized credentials. The integration of the NETLAB+ virtual environment into every course allows for practical, hands-on experience, crucial for understanding contemporary IT technologies.

Goals and Achievements

Northark set five primary goals for this project, resulting in the following outcomes:

  • Goal 1: Expand Delivery: The IT program now features both online and face-to-face options, allowing students to choose their preferred learning modality. The introduction of the AS in Cybersecurity and AS in IT provides more focused pathways for students.
  • Goal 2: Modify the Curriculum: The incorporation of NETLAB+ and alignment with national certifications enhances the educational framework. The grant has facilitated access to certification exams for students, resulting in about 20 students passing various CompTIA exams, including A+, Network+, and Security+.
  • Goal 3: Improve Completion Opportunities: In addition to flexible scheduling and delivery modes, the program now allows students to begin their studies in any semester. While many students appreciate this flexibility, some have chosen to extend their time in the program, potentially taking fewer classes while managing work commitments.
  • Goal 4: Strengthen Business Engagement: The Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) now includes at least five companies that employ remote IT technicians, reflecting the shift toward remote work that many employers adopted during the pandemic. This collaboration ensures that the program remains relevant to current job market needs.
  • Goal 5: Recruit and Retain Rural Students: Recruitment efforts have been robust, with faculty and staff engaging in professional development and outreach to local K-12 schools, STEM events, and career fairs. This proactive approach has resulted in more opportunities for promoting the IT program.

Professional Development and Sharing Best Practices

Project faculty and staff have participated in extensive professional development to enhance their effectiveness. They have presented at several conferences including the Hi-Tec conference, the ATE PI Conference, and the Arkansas Community Colleges conference, sharing insights and best practices regarding the program changes. Participation in Summer Working Connections has further enriched their teaching methodologies, directly impacting course content and delivery.

Conclusion

The NSF ATE-funded project at North Arkansas College has successfully redefined IT education in this rural area by increasing accessibility, flexibility, and relevance of the curriculum using methods that can be scaled. The program’s alignment with national certifications, coupled with enhanced delivery methods, positions students for success in a rapidly evolving job market. The initiative not only addresses current workforce needs but also prepares students for future challenges in the field of information technology.
